R(X):=R_{\rho, \Lambda}(X)=\inf \left\{\alpha \in \mathbb{R}: \Lambda(X)+\alpha \in A_{\rho}\right\}, \quad X \in \mathrm{CB}\left(L^{\infty}\right)
$$

It is straightforward to verify that such map is a convex SRM. It can be monetary or coherent, by dropping or demanding the necessary properties for both $\Lambda$ and $\rho$. Now, by translation invariance,

$$
R(X):=R_{A, \Lambda}(X)=\inf \{\alpha \in \mathbb{R}: \Lambda(X+\dot{\alpha}) \in A\}, \quad X \in \mathrm{CB}\left(L^{\infty}\right)
$$

where $A$ is a convex acceptance set. Both maps coincide over $A=A_{\rho}$ or $\rho=\rho_{A}$. or This is the case for $\Lambda(X)=$ essinf $X$. In this case we get that $R(X)=-\inf _{x \in X}$ essinf $x=$

$\sup _{x \in X} \mathrm{ML}(x)$, where ML stands for the maximum loss risk measure.
Example 5.5. A usual risk-neutral stochastic problem has the form

$$
\min _{a \in A}\langle p, \ell(a, x)\rangle
$$

where $A$ is a set of possible/allowable actions, $x \in\left(L^{\infty}\right)^{n}$, and $\ell: A \times \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is a suitable loss function. A possible risk-averse counterpart to the above is

$$
\min _{a \in A} \rho(\ell(a, x))
$$

which, in the conditions of Theorem 4.2, can be extended to

$$
\min _{a \in A} R(\ell(a, X))=\min _{a \in A} \sup _{x \in X} \rho(\ell(a, x)), \quad X \in \operatorname{CB}\left(L^{\infty}\right)^{n}
$$

A natural question that arises in this venue is whether this problem is robust, in the sense of how it responds to small perturbations in $X$. We have the following result.

Proposition 5.6. Assume $R$ is WC-bounded monetary SRM. If $X_{n} \xrightarrow{\epsilon} X$, and $\bigcup_{n \in \mathbb{N}} X_{n}$ is precompact, then

$$
\min _{a \in A} R\left(\ell\left(a, X_{n}\right)\right) \rightarrow \min _{a \in A} R(\ell(a, X))
$$

Proof. In this case we have that the sequence $\left\{f_{n}, n \geqslant 1\right\}$ as defined in the proof of Theorem 4.2 is tight. By item (iii) in Lemma 4.1, hypo-convergence then implies convergence and finiteness of the supremum. Hence, we have that

$$
\sup _{x \in X_{n}} R(\dot{x})=\sup _{x \in X} f_{n}(x) \rightarrow \sup _{x \in X} f(x)=\sup _{x \in X} R(\dot{x})
$$

Thus, we have $R\left(X_{n}\right) \rightarrow R(X)$. For ease of notation, let $g_{n}, g: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be defined as $g_{n}(a)=R\left(\ell\left(a, X_{n}\right)\right)$ for each $n \in \mathbb{N}$, and $g(a)=R(\ell(a, X))$. Then, we have that $g_{n} \rightarrow g$ pointwise. That is, if $a_{n} \rightarrow a$, then $g_{n}\left(a_{n}\right)=R\left(\ell\left(a_{n}, X_{n}\right)\right) \rightarrow R(\ell(a, X))=g(a)$, which implies epi $g_{n} \xrightarrow{\epsilon}$ epi $g$. Now, take

$$
a_{n}^{*} \in \underset{a \in A}{\arg \min } R\left(\ell\left(a, X_{n}\right)\right)
$$

for each $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Since, translation invariance and monotonicity imply $|R(X)| \leqslant\|X\|$ for any $X \in \mathrm{CB}\left(L^{\infty}\right)$, we get that $\left\{a_{n}^{*}, n \geqslant 1\right\}$ is bounded since $\bigcup_{n \in \mathbb{N}} X_{n}$ is precompact, and hence bounded. Then, by the Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem, $a_{n}^{*}$ converges

(by taking a sub-sequence if needed). Thus, from item (ii) in Lemma 4.1 we get that $\inf _{a \in A} R\left(\ell\left(a, X_{n}\right)\right) \rightarrow \inf _{a \in A} R(\ell(a, X))$. The claim follows, since the infimum is attained.

Example 5.7. It is well known that risk measures are closely linked to preferences. In fact, a traditional risk measure $\rho: L^{\infty} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ induces a preference relation $x \bar{\leqslant} y$ if and only if $\rho(x) \geqslant \rho(y)$. For more details, see, for example, Drapeau and Kupper (2013). Following this idea, our SRM also induces a preference relation over $\mathrm{CB}\left(L^{\infty}\right)$, which can be understood as one basket of goods being preferred to another. Specifically, we define the preference order $\leqslant$ by setting $X \leqslant Y$ if and only if $R(X) \geqslant R(Y)$. There are several studies on the representation of preferences over sets of goods; see, for instance, Kreps (1979); Dekel et al. (2001, 2007). These works often rely on the concept of a "subjective state space," which can be challenging to identify explicitly. By Lemma 1 and Theorem 3 of Dekel et al. (2001), if $R$ is a continuous convex SRM, then it satisfies set-convexity and admits a representation of the form

$$
R(-X)=u\left(\left(\sup _{x \in X} \mathfrak{u}(q, x)\right)_{q \in S}\right)
$$

where $S$ is a state space, $\mathfrak{u}: S \times L^{\infty} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is a state-dependent expected utility function that is affine in the second argument, and $u$ is an increasing aggregator function. In light of Theorem 3.2, we can take $S=U_{+}$,

$$
\mathfrak{u}(q, x)=\langle\hat{q}, x\rangle-\tau_{R}(\mu), \quad \text { and } \quad u(\psi)=\max _{\mu \in \mathbf{b a}_{1,+}^{T}}\left\{\int_{U_{+}} \psi(q) \mathrm{d} \mu(q)\right\}
$$

for admissible $\psi$; eq. (5.1) is recovered by taking $\psi(q)=\sup _{x \in X} \mathfrak{u}(q, x)$. The idea here is that the agent chooses a basket of assets (say, $X$ ), and then he evaluates the utility of this choice when the "latent state" $q$ is revealed. A preference order $\bar{\leqslant}$ on the space of random variables admits a representation via an affine risk measure $\rho$ if and only if it satisfies the independence and Archimedean properties (Drapeau and Kupper, 2013, Proposition 1). This result extends to the preference order $\bar{\leqslant}$ on sets of random variables, as established in Theorem 4 of Dekel et al. (2001) and Theorem S2 of Dekel et al. (2007). Specifically, a preference order $\leqslant$ over sets of random variables admits a representation via an affine SRM $R$ if and only if it satisfies the independence and Archimedean properties. In this case, there exists a measure $\mu \in \mathbf{b a}_{1,+}^{T}$ such that $R(X)=\int_{U_{+}}\langle\hat{q},-X\rangle \mathrm{d} \mu(q)-\tau_{R}(\mu)$.

abstract:
We introduce the concept of set risk measures (SRMs), which are real-valued
maps defined on the space of all non-empty, closed, and bounded sets of almost
surely bounded random variables. Traditional risk measures typically operate on
spaces of random variables, but SRMs extend this framework to sets of random
variables. We establish an axiom scheme for SRMs, similar to classical risk
measures but adapted for set operations. The main technical contribution is an
axiomatic dual representation of convex SRMs by using regular, finitely
additive measures on the unit ball of the dual space of essentially bounded
random variables. We explore worst-case SRMs, which evaluate risk as the
supremum of individual risks within a set, and provide a collection of examples
illustrating the applicability of our framework to systemic risk, portfolio
optimization, and decision-making under uncertainty. This work extends the
theory of risk measures to a more general and flexible setup, accommodating a
broader range of financial and mathematical applications.
